importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating when the news about Andrew Stanton's charges was released to the public.
When authorities first began investigating Stanton's online activity due to a tip from the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center.
The date when a US Customs and Border Patrol supervisor contacted Stanton via text, prompting a hostile response from him, which is detailed in the criminal complaint.
The date of the murder of Charlie Kirk, which Stanton allegedly referenced in a TikTok video, linking it to a call for similar violence.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Andrew Stanton posted multiple threatening TikTok videos, from August to October 2025, leading to federal charges.

keyTakeAways: A 38-year-old man from Kenosha, Wisconsin, Andrew Stanton, was indicted by federal prosecutors on three charges, including threatening to assault, kidnap, or murder a U.S. official.

Stanton was charged for posting a series of TikTok videos calling for the killing of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents, including a video in which he said, 'If they (ICE) show up to your neighborhood…it’s time we start shooting at you.'
In one September video, Stanton allegedly said, 'do a lot more Charlie Kirks,' referencing the September 10 murder of political activist Charlie Kirk.

Stanton also posted videos with text such as 'a violent state can only be stopped with violence in return' and 'I think we should be OFFING federal agents,' and claimed 'you have to use bullets' to stop violence.
The Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center flagged his online activity in August after a tip regarding his inquiry about the Israeli military in Illinois and Wisconsin.

Federal agents tried to contact Stanton multiple times in early September, including a text from a US Customs and Border Patrol supervisor, which resulted in a hostile response and a request to meet in person.
Stanton pleaded not guilty during his arraignment and is currently in detention pending trial, with a pretrial conference scheduled for December 1, 2025, and a trial set for December 15, 2025.
This case reflects broader national concerns about attacks on federal law enforcement, especially in the context of heightened tensions around immigration enforcement under the Trump administration.

namedEntities.name: Andrew Stanton
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 38-year-old man from Kenosha, Wisconsin, charged with making threatening TikTok videos calling for the killing of ICE agents and threatening federal law enforcement officers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central figure in the article, the individual who posted threatening videos and was formally charged with threatening federal officials.

namedEntities.name: ICE (Immigration and Customs Enforcement)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal law enforcement agency responsible for immigration enforcement and border control.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The target of Stanton's threats in the TikTok videos, highlighting the vulnerability of federal agents during periods of public tension over immigration policies.

namedEntities.name: Charlie Kirk
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A conservative political activist who was murdered on September 10, 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Stanton allegedly referenced the killing in a TikTok video, saying 'do a lot more Charlie Kirks,' indicating a potential connection to extremist or violent ideology.

namedEntities.name: Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal office that tracks suspected terrorist activity and suspicious behavior.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of a tip that led federal investigators to begin monitoring Andrew Stanton’s online activity in August 2025.

namedEntities.name: US Customs and Border Patrol
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal law enforcement agency under the Department of Homeland Security that oversees border security and immigration enforcement.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A federal agency that attempted to contact Stanton, resulting in a hostile exchange that escalated the case.

namedEntities.name: Federal Prosecutors
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Officials who brought charges against Andrew Stanton under federal law.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They formally charged Stanton with threatening federal officials and are central to the legal proceedings described in the article.

namedEntities.name: TikTok
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A social media platform where Andrew Stanton posted threatening videos.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The platform used to disseminate the threatening content, illustrating how social media can be exploited for radical or violent expression.

namedEntities.name: US District Court (Milwaukee)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal court in Milwaukee where Andrew Stanton appeared for arraignment and where the case is being prosecuted.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The venue where the legal proceedings against Stanton took place, including his arraignment and upcoming trial.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 38-year-old man from Kenosha, Wisconsin, Andrew Stanton, has been charged by federal prosecutors with threatening to assault, kidnap, or murder U.S. federal officials, specifically Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents, after posting a series of threatening TikTok videos between August and October 2025. In one video, he called for ICE agents to be shot and said, 'If they show up to your neighborhood, it’s time we start shooting at you.' Another video referenced the September 10 murder of conservative political activist Charlie Kirk, with Stanton allegedly saying 'do a lot more Charlie Kirks.' Authorities began investigating after a tip from the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center flagged his inquiry about Israeli military locations. Federal agents attempted contact with Stanton, who responded with hostility, including a request to meet in person. Stanton pleaded not guilty and remains in federal detention, with a pretrial conference scheduled for December 1, 2025, and a trial set for December 15, 2025. This case reflects broader national tensions over immigration enforcement and the rising threat of violence against federal agents.
title: Wisconsin man charged after posting TikTok videos calling for the killing of ICE agents, prosecutors say
